title: 106_hr1444
content: The Act titled "Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Act of 2000" defines terms like Pacific Ocean drainage area, Program, and Secretary for the implementation of the Act. The Program is established under SEC. 3. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program is established within the Department of the Interior with the goals of reducing fish mortality due to water withdrawal for irrigation and other purposes, as well as decreasing the entry of fish into water supply systems. The Secretary will develop projects to mitigate impacts on fisheries. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program, established within the Department of the Interior, aims to reduce fish mortality and prevent fish entry into water supply systems. Projects will be developed to mitigate impacts on fisheries resulting from water diversions by local governmental entities in the Pacific Ocean drainage area, including the development of fish screens, fish passage devices, and other related features. The Secretary will prioritize projects with a total cost under $5,000,000, based on inventories by States on the need for projects related to fish mortality prevention and water supply system impacts. SEC. 4. PARTICIPATION IN THE PROGRAM. Non-Federal participation is voluntary. The Secretary will not hold non-Federal entities financially responsible unless they apply to participate. Federal projects on U.S. land are nonreimbursable. SEC. 5. EVALUATION AND PRIORITIZATION OF PROJECTS. Evaluation and prioritization of projects under the Program is based on benefits to native fish species, water diversion size, funding availability, cost effectiveness, and potential biological or water system benefits. Eligibility requirements are also outlined. Eligibility requirements for projects under the Program include meeting Secretary and State requirements, agreement by all relevant entities, consultation with various agencies, and use of available data. The non-Federal share of the cost for projects on non-Federal land is 35 percent, with non-Federal participants providing necessary land and resources. Contributions from non-Federal entities will be credited towards the project. The non-Federal share of project costs on non-Federal land is 35 percent, with contributions such as rights-of-way, dredged material disposal areas, and relocations credited towards the project. Non-Federal participants are responsible for all costs on non-Federal land, while the Federal Government covers costs on Federal land or facilities. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON ELIGIBILITY FOR FUNDING. A project funded under this Act cannot receive Federal funds from any other source for the same purpose. SEC. 9. REPORT. A project funded under this Act cannot receive Federal funds from any other source for the same purpose. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress after the third fiscal year, detailing completed projects, those to be completed in the future, and recommended Program changes based on project outcomes. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of Appropriations: $25,000,000 authorized annually for fiscal years 2001-2005. Limitations include not more than 25% of funds for projects in a single state, with a waiver option if the state cannot utilize the full amount. Administrative expenses capped at 6%. The State may not use the full funding allocated under the Act. Administrative expenses are limited to 6% of the funds authorized for each fiscal year.
